sub_topic: Applying the Fourier transform to signal processing
message_1: A signal $f(t) = 5\cos(3\pi t) + 3\sin(5\pi t)$ is given. Find the Fourier transform of the signal and plot the magnitude and phase spectra.
message_2:
To find the Fourier transform of the given signal, we can use the following formula:

$$F(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) e^{-j\omega t} dt$$

First, let's rewrite the given signal using Euler's formula:

$$f(t) = 5\cos(3\pi t) + 3\sin(5\pi t) = \frac{5}{2}(e^{j3\pi t} + e^{-j3\pi t}) + \frac{3}{2j}(e^{j5\pi t} - e^{-j5\pi t})$$

Now, we can find the Fourier transform of each term separately:

$$F(\omega) = \frac{5}{2}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} (e^{j3\pi t} + e^{-j3\pi t}) e^{-j\omega t} dt + \frac{3}{2j}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} (e^{j5\pi t} - e^{-j5\pi t}) e^{-j\omega t} dt$$

Using the property of linearity, we can split the integrals:

$$F(\omega) = \frac{5}{2}\left[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{j(3\pi - \omega) t} dt + \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-j(3\pi + \omega) t} dt\right] + \frac{3}{2j}\left[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{j(5\pi - \omega) t} dt - \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-j(5\pi + \omega) t} dt\right]$$

Now, we can use the Dirac delta function property:

$$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{j(\alpha - \omega) t} dt = 2\pi\delta(\omega - \alpha)$$

Applying this property to our integrals, we get:

$$F(\omega) = \frac{5}{2}\left[2\pi\delta(\omega - 3\pi) + 2\pi\delta(\omega + 3\pi)\right] + \frac{3}{2j}\left[2\pi\delta(\omega - 5\pi) - 2\pi\delta(\omega + 5\pi)\right]$$

Simplifying, we have:

$$F(\omega) = 5\pi\left[\delta(\omega - 3\pi) + \delta(\omega + 3\pi)\right] + \frac{3\pi}{j}\left[\delta(\omega - 5\pi) - \delta(\omega + 5\pi)\right]$$

Now, we can find the magnitude and phase spectra:

Magnitude: $$|F(\omega)| = 5\pi\left[|\delta(\omega - 3\pi)| + |\delta(\omega + 3\pi)|\right] + 3\pi\left[|\delta(\omega - 5\pi)| + |\delta(\omega + 5\pi)|\right]$$

Phase: $$\angle F(\omega) = \begin{cases} 0, & \text{for } \omega = \pm 3\pi \\ \pm\frac{\pi}{2}, & \text{for } \omega = \pm 5\pi \\ \text{undefined}, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$

To plot the magnitude and phase spectra, you would create two separate plots. In the magnitude plot, you would have two spikes at $\omega = \pm 3\pi$ with a height of $5\pi$ and two spikes at $\omega = \pm 5\pi$ with a height of $3\pi$. In the phase plot, you would have a phase of 0 at $\omega = \pm 3\pi$ and a phase of $\pm\frac{\pi}{2}$ at $\omega = \pm 5\pi$. The phase is undefined for all other values of $\omega$.
